results.title: Here They Know You
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “School’s Out”.
In country towns, opportunities for school leavers are limited. Diane and Peter have left school but don’t have jobs. They reflect on the relevance of school, the sense of community in a country town and the advantages of city and country life

results.title: Solar dawn (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Kay Roberts, Gareth Cole and Solarscope Films
results.brief_description: Utilises many animation sequences to clearly show how basic solar collectors work. It shows how buildings can be heated and cooled by solar devices, and how city buildings and ordinary houses should be designed to take advantage of direct solar energy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kay Roberts, Gareth Cole and Solarscope Films

results.title: High Hopes
results.brief_description: Lyn and Patrice leave school with definite plans for their careers. Following long periods unemployed they reassess their aspirations and finally accept jobs they didn’t really want.

results.creator_credit: Sydney University Television Services and Apace Research

results.title: John Lethbridge
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
John Lethbridge’s works, his paintings, drawings and sculptural installations develop out of a personal necessity to try to give an order to the rituals and repeating experiences of life that recur in an apparently unordered and random world. His recent work can be described as “Post Conceptual Romanticism”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions

results.title: New life new country
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Fatma Coskun and ACMI
results.brief_description: Fatma Coskun came from a small village amongst the mountains of Corun. However, financial hardships drove her and her husband to Australia to start a new life. Despite a major setback at the beginning of their journey, Fatma and her family consider themselves very fortunate to have settled in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Fatma Coskun and ACMI
